In @BatmanvSuperman  the question remains  would the @realDonaldTrump deport Superman for being an illegal alien in the USA?
In @BatmanvSuperman  I've gotta side with Superman. He’s a space alien from an exoplanet. In astrophysics  that’s how we roll
Met Superman a few years ago at the Hayden Planetarium. I helped him find Krypton. A very nice man. https://t.co/OYS7oy91Zj
Not that anybody asked  but Gregorian calendar rules unintentionally prevent eclipses from ever occurring on Easter Sunday
Happy March Equinox to all residents of planet Earth: First day of Spring North of the Equator;  First day of Autumn  South.
Mother Nature has been genetically modifying organisms for nearly four-billion years. Farmers for ten-thousand years.
Happy Pi-day to all. Posted my best Pi-tweets a year ago. So today  I’ll just wish a happy 137th Birthday to Albert Einstein.
People who are anti-Trump are actually anti-Trump supporters — they oppose free citizens voting for the @realDonaldTrump.
I occasionally wonder whether the entire Universe is nothing more than a snow-globe on the living room mantle of an Alien.
I also recreationally consume large quantities of dihydrogen monoxide. On the street  I pay up to $2 000 per megagram for it.
Before every tweet  I take deep hits of gaseous cocktails comprised of 78% N2 and 21% O2. A long-revered elixir of life.
I’m simultaneously flattered and disturbed when  after posting various tweets  people tweet back wondering if I’m on drugs.
The closest thing to fatally passing through a portal into another dimension is when fish get yanked out of water  then eaten
I hear that the flat-Earth movement may be gaining momentum all around the globe.
Who'd have thought altering Wolf genes to create Dogs would imbue delight for riding in cars with their head out the window.
Welcome back to Earth  Scott Kelly. After a year in orbit  Relativity says you’re 1/100 sec younger than you’d otherwise be.
With my 5 000 000th follower  I reaffirm that it’s an honor and a privilege to rub your geek underbellies in the Twitterverse
Who would Jesus vote for? To him walls  wealth  & torture are non-starters  so probably the Jewish New Yorker from Vermont.
The Leap Day is misnamed. We’re not leaping anywhere. The calendar is simply  and abruptly  catching up with Earth’s orbit
One's quest in life should not solely be the search for answers. Why not find pleasure in posing the questions themselves.
Let's just confess that our best 4D portal  through which products are transported  is the drive-thru window at McDonalds.
Maybe what I really want is wormhole-shipping. Buy something online. A 4D portal opens and a person hands you the product.
I wonder if workplaces contain too many bosses basking in compliments given by people who rely on them for their paychecks.
I wonder what Cannibals & Aztecs would say  watching civilized people eat symbolic hearts of loved ones on Valentine’s Day.
1916: Einstein predicts Gravity Waves. 1917: He lays the foundation for Lasers. 2016: Gravity Waves discovered using Lasers.
If you never make mistakes then you are not on the frontier of discovery  for there is where mistakes are made all the time.
If Earth rotated 10x faster in the opposite direction then Coriolis forces would’ve helped the @Panthers make that Field Goal
Every day where someone could have made a discovery but cultural or political forces impede it  is a sad day for civilization
“Look at that  you son of a bitch." https://t.co/JyeiOV7lgv
In science  when human behavior  enters the equation  things go nonlinear. That's why Physics is easy and Sociology is hard.
Sad Banana. https://t.co/QNx4xv51co
Dear @bobatl  as an astrophysicist I don’t rap  but I know people who do. This one has my back: https://t.co/BbMi4tzHLz
The Cosmos is knowable. When childhood curiosity persists as an adult  it inoculates against others telling you what to think
Seedless grapes. Seedless oranges. Seedless watermelons. All good. My vote for the next fruit to invent: Seedless pomegranate
Curious how we’re more like to bond with one another based on what we believe is true rather than on what is objectively true
With Lotteries funding State education budgets  the best way to sustain them is to NOT teach probability&statistics in school
I wonder if some forms of creativity can only be generated by a Space Oddity that Falls to Earth. RIP #DavidBowie (1947-2016)
Space aliens would surely think it odd that one way humans express affection is the simultaneous exchange of saliva.
To all those who reckon time on the Gregorian Calendar - Happy New Year!  (FYI:  January 1 is astronomically  insignificant.)
FYI:  By the end of the Twelve Days of Christmas song  your home is crammed with 23 flying Birds and 50 hyperactive Humans.
Male & female Reindeer grow antlers  but males lose them in winter. All Santa’s reindeer  Rudolph too  are therefore female.
As Earth warms  and Arctic ice melts  Santa will lose his habitat too. Soon we’ll see photos of him clutched to an ice floe.
Merry Christmas to the world’s Christians  and to all the non-Christians who celebrate Christmas just for the heaven of it.
I was once anti-biotic. But lately I've been more pro-biotic after reading more about their culture.
There is power in Knowledge  but there is greater power in Wisdom
“We all came from the sea”  — JFKennedy (1962).  Back when US politicians understood basic Biology.
As climate change reshapes the World’s coastlines  rich people lose their second homes. Poor people lose their only homes.
Odd that we live in a world where even objective truths count as controversial subjects.
There is nothing in the US Constitution that protects you from being offended by the truth.
Now that robots move their limbs smoothly and with grace  I wonder how we’re supposed to imitate them on the dance floor.
There are no right or wrong opinions  unless you have invalidated yours for having ignored facts that conflict with them.
3 400: Americans who died by Terrorism since 2001  3 400: Americans who died by household Firearms since five weeks ago.
400 000: Americans who died fighting in World War II.  400 000: Americans who died by household Firearms since 2001
1.4 Million: Americans who died in all Wars fought since 1776.  1.4 Million: Americans who died via household Guns since 1968
After several Steven Segal films in a row  you'd think bad guys would know to avoid rooms that contain both him & a PoolTable
Odd that politicians who change their mind are often criticized by those who don’t  as though ossified thoughts were a virtue
The actual Sun (as a Jack-o-Lantern) wishes everyone on Earth a Happy Halloween. (via @NASASunEarth) https://t.co/jheDVwb9mI
When a Doctor’s prognosis is bad  we want to seek a second opinion. But when a prognosis is good we’re somehow okay with it.
I fear a future in which Autocorrect achieves consciousness  becomes our texting overlord  and destabilizes civilization.
Because you know I’m all about that data  ‘bout that data. No trouble. I’m all about that data  ‘bout that data. No trouble.
The 1989 film “Back to the Future II” imagined life on Oct 21  2015: Pocket Digital Cameras [Got it] https://t.co/62vF17cjQB
As the Geekiverse knows well  today is “Back to the Future II Day”.  So let’s do this... https://t.co/kWepmtsirX
Not that anybody asked  but the Irresistible Force beats the Immovable Object — every time.
CALLING ALL GEEKS:  Must root for @Cubs — to fulfill their Prophesy in "Back the Future II" http://t.co/OPDCb6JTuq
#WhenIWasYourAge it was people who were smart  and phones that were dumb.
#WhenMyParentsWereYourAge “In God We Trust" was neither on our money  the Pledge of Allegiance  or the front wall of Congress
#WhenIWasYourAge Photographs were records of your life experience  and not the life experience itself.
The @MartianMovie — where the protagonist survives not on Wit  Prayer  or Hope. but by “Sciencing the Shit" out of everything
Evidence that the @MartianMovie is fantasy: All who make important decisions are scientifically literate.
Guns don’t kill people. Bullets kill people. Fired from guns  brandished by people  who shoot you by accident or on purpose.
Imagine a world where Nations find the search for life in the Universe more interesting than the taking of life on Earth.
Ed @Snowden  after discussing everything from Chemistry to the Constitution on #StarTalk  you're a patriot to me. Stay safe.
Congratulations to @TrevorNoah tonight. @TheDailyShow's new opening credits now show Earth rotating in the correct direction.
Resist the Hype: The size of today’s “Super” moon is to next month’s full moon as a 16.07 inch pizza is to a 16.00 inch pizza
Sept 23: Happy Equinox to all Earthlings. One of only two annual days when the Sun everywhere rises due East & sets due West.
If your Personal Beliefs deny what’s objectively true about the world  then they're more accurately called Personal Delusions
There's no greater incentive to lie than the threat of punishment for telling the truth.
If your body were bolted to the ground when Earth stopped rotating  then your head would snap off  and it would roll due east
If Earth stopped rotating  everyone not bolted to the ground would fall over and roll due east at the speed of a jet plane.
An informed opinion is never based on somebody else’s opinion  lest you empower others to do your thinking for you.
Any time we're impressed by what a non-human animal does  it's simply because we previously underestimated its intelligence.
The latest Hi-Res image. I told everybody it wasn’t a planet  but nobody listened. (via @DavidBerthod) http://t.co/3m5HNiKyGJ
Just an FYI: All table salt is sea salt. Mined salt just happens to come from long-buried  evaporated  prehistoric seas.
Well  if you’re not part of the Solution  then you must be part of the Precipitate.
A Geeky joke I'm compelled to share: In Chemistry class the cylinders know more than you do because they're already graduated
Odd that we select the heads of agencies by who is most qualified. But we select Presidents by whose personality we like best
Odd. Those who feel superior are often compelled to tell others  presumably because it’s not otherwise obvious to anyone.
Maybe I just have an active imagination  but I’m still a bit spooked by the wall outlets in Australia: http://t.co/6g9xUnmETm
And yes  over the years  my relationship with Pluto has been strictly Plutonic.
The next time anybody asks me about my religion  I think I’ll reply “Geek Orthodox”
Dear Pluto  Lookin’ good. But you’re still a Dwarf Planet — get over it. Love  Neil deGrasse Tyson http://t.co/qBBD9feG6e
Evidence for global warming comes in many forms. http://t.co/zN3U83ETZH
I once showed Pluto to Pluto. He looked delighted. Or maybe that’s his reaction to everything. http://t.co/mhLZ5t7LoN
Enjoying colorful fireworks tonight? Thank Aluminum Barium Calcium Chlorine Copper Iron Nitrogen Oxygen Sodium & Strontium.
As I get older  I’ve become more and more intolerant of intolerance.
The Moon continually tugs on Earth’s rotation  slowing us down bit by bit. To compensate  Tuesday  June 30 gets a leap second
Name-calling is what happens when you desperately want to argue  but you are in fact inarticulate.
The day with most sunlight: Happy Summer Solstice to Earth residents north of the equator. Now thru Dec 21 days get shorter.
If you're good at BS'ing others  then all it means is that you rarely hang around people who are smarter than you.
My favorite line in "The Martian" trailer  uttered by Matt Damon  is “I’m going to have to science the shit out of this.”
In 5-billion yrs the Sun will expand & engulf our orbit as the charred ember that was once Earth vaporizes. Have a nice day.
Just an FYI: Stepping on an Ant is equivalent to a creature 10 000 times more massive than a Blue Whale stepping on you.
From what I have seen of society  the number of people who will tell you what you cannot accomplish in life is limitless.
Still distracted by the fact that "The Los Angeles @Angels" baseball team literally translates to "The The Angels Angels"
Curious fact that those who never fail are also those who never truly succeed.
For Algebra Geeks: If the thickness of a pizza is A  and its radius is Z  and pi is just PI  then its volume is V = PIZZA.
Last one: The Latinized name for Earth is Terra. If you are human "of the Earth" you are Terrable. (Just kidding  Earthlings)
At The Who concert listening to 71yr old R. Daltrey & 70 yr old P. Townsend sing their lyric "I hope I die before I get old."
I wonder who was the first person to see a bird soaring high above & think it a good idea to capture it and lock it in a cage
Curious fact that any time we lose a person who sings the Blues  as we just did in #BBKing  the World becomes a sadder place.
When flight attendants say "Cabin is pressurized for your comfort” they mean "so you don't suffocate from oxygen deprivation"
Okay to encourage others to pull themselves up by their bootstraps. But if you do  just remember  some people have no boots.
If you removed all the arteries  veins  & capillaries from a person's body  and tied them end-to-end  the person will die.
Our “Common Sense" is not derived from what is true in Nature but from the limits on how our senses interact with Nature.
The less evidence we have for what we believe is certain  the more violently we defend beliefs against those who don't agree.
Seems to me  every day should be Earth Day.
Okay to not know. But when you don't know  yet think you know  and wield power in that ignorance  it's a recipe for disaster.
If there is a cat Heaven  and if cat Heaven has mice for cats to chase  seems to me that cat Heaven must then be mice Hell.
If you're curious: First mammals to orbit Earth  in order: Dog  Guinea Pig  Mouse  Russian Human  Chimpanzee  American Human.
On #FamilyGuy Brian sweats  But Dogs don’t have sweat glands. I then figured Dogs don’t talk either. So I left that one alone
The word “awesome" once described things like Moon landings & cures for disease. Today  it’s an unexpected feature in an App.
As we did last year  Ozzie and I wish all Christians (and Bunny lovers) a Happy Easter. http://t.co/4CJ0bocXZZ
Another way to look at “Religious Freedom” laws  is that they give you the legal right to make less money.
If the Pledge of Allegiance told the truth: http://t.co/Iy5zoyMOls
Ever notice how Vampires & dead people  who sit up in their caskets  do so with a straight back? They must have good abs.
Every now and then I get the impression that people would rather react before they think.
If I were ever abducted by aliens  the first thing I’d ask is whether they came from a planet where people also deny science.
Cool.  The Moon  Sun  International Space Station  & Earth  all lined up.  via @ObservingSpace http://t.co/S0N4emt0Pn
This morning's Moon is about the same phase & sky position captured by Van Gogh in "The Starry Night" http://t.co/BWvbF07mKl
You’re curious -- I can feel it. How many digits of Pi before the numerals 0123456789 appear in sequence? 17 387 594 879
Ongoing research continues to demonstrate conclusively that your IQ is an excellent predictor of your score on an IQ test.
If we were honest about shortcomings of human physiology then "optical illusions” would instead be labeled “brain failures”.
Good education is not what fills your head with facts but what stimulates curiosity. You then learn for the rest of your life
You should all know by now that if you accuse me of being a Nerd or a Geek  I’ll simply take it as a compliment and move on.
Had to wait in line to renew a Passport allowing me to visit members of my own species across artificially conceived borders.
Just an FYI:  A 250 lb football player  running 15 mph  has more kinetic energy than a bullet fired from an AK-47 rifle.
Occasionally I wonder what a football game would be like if played by Zombies. Would be slower  but oh so much more violent.
Enjoying colorful fireworks in Arizona? Thank Aluminum Barium Calcium Chlorine Copper Iron Nitrogen Oxygen Sodium & Strontium
I love the smell of the Universe — in the evening.
Not enough of us reflect on how modern civilization pivots on the discoveries of just a few intellectually restless people.
For the Patriots to blame a change in temperature for 15% lower-pressures  requires balls to be inflated with 125-degree air.
I dream of a world where the truth is what shapes people's politics  rather than politics shaping what people think is true.
if I am ever abducted by aliens  I just may be compelled to ask  “Do you have Hoverboards on your home planet?"
Students who earn straight "A"s in school do so not because of good Teachers but in spite of bad Teachers.
Wouldn't it be cool if Zombies & Vampires became human if we bit them first? Somebody needs to test that hypothesis.
Happy Hew Year to all on the Gregorian calendar. Today  Earth completes yet another 939 950 000 km journey around the Sun.
By 2015  Apollo 11 will be as long ago as 1923 was to the Moon landing itself. And I don’t know what we have to show for it.
Imagine a world in which we are all enlightened by objective truths rather than offended by them.
Santa knows Physics: Of all colors  Red Light penetrates fog best. That's why Benny the Blue-nosed reindeer never got the gig
Merry Christmas to all. A Pagan holiday (BC) becomes a Religious holiday (AD). Which then becomes a Shopping holiday (USA).
On this day long ago  a child was born who  by age 30  would transform the world. Happy Birthday Isaac Newton b. Dec 25  1642
QUESTION: ThIs year  what do all the world's Muslims and Jews call December 25th? ANSWER: Thursday
If we had twelve fingers  there’d be no middle finger to flip at people with whom you’ve run out of words to communicate.
December 20  1975: 17 years old  I visited Carl Sagan at Cornell University. His Appt. Book that day. http://t.co/tlWgQwsrqO
On some issues  I’m a staunch Conservative — like curtailing greenhouse gas emissions so that we can Conserve the environment
Aliens  seeing Humans kill over land  politics  religion  & skin color  would surely ask  “What the f*%k is wrong with you?"
Just because you can't figure out how ancient civilizations built stuff  doesn't mean they got help from Aliens.
#WhenIWasYourAge: Religion was taught in Sunday School  not in your Science Classroom.
Times Have Changed: Officer kills an unarmed Black man  spawning National protests. When I grew up  this was just local news.
I wonder if Atheists eat at T.G.I. Fridays.
Our image of evil space aliens surely derives from a fear that they will treat us just as we treat one another.
Odd that drivers of fuel efficient cars often get more green-praise than those who chose to live where they can walk to work.
Mysteries of #Interstellar: In this unreal future  they teach unscientific things in science class. Oh  wait. That is real.
Mysteries of #Interstellar: Can’t imagine a future where escaping Earth via wormhole is a better plan than just fixing Earth.
In #Interstellar: They explore a planet near a Black Hole. Personally  I’d stay as far the hell away from BlackHoles as I can
In #Interstellar  if you didn’t understand the plot  there is no published book to help you.
In #Interstellar: On another planet  around another star  in another part of the galaxy  two guys get into a fist fight.
In #Interstellar: Of the leading characters (all of whom are scientists or engineers) half are women. Just an FYI.
Relativity. Gravity. Quantum. Electrodynamics. Evolution. Each of these theories is true  whether or not you believe in them.
Stay calm. Just because Republicans took control over the Senate  doesn't mean Global Warming is any less true than before.
Proud to be Homo sapiens. A curious species with DNA compelling us to explore  even if doing so puts your own life at risk.
Pope Francis announced that he now embraces the science of Evolution & the Big Bang. Hmm. I wonder if he just watched Cosmos?
In Court you can win even if ideas you defend are not true.  But in science  Nature is the ultimate judge  jury & executioner
I wonder if social media atheists ever use "OMG".  If so  they probably intended to type "OYG".
The objective truths of the world are controversial only to people who are both under-informed and who like to argue.
Today’s date is 10 / 10 / 2014.  It’s so rare that it will never happen again.
Plants get their energy from the Sun. Herbivores from plants. Carnivores from herbivores. In the end  we're all solar powered
I wonder how much talent has evaporated from the world  for lack of ambition to drive it.
There are surely problems in the universe so advanced that our human brain cannot see them as problems in need of solution.
I think not enough good Hot Chocolate is served in the world. A comfort food without equal.
A news headline you hardly ever see:  "Psychic Wins the Lottery Again"

For survival in this world  it’s to an animal's great advantage if Humans think you're cute.
If your belief system is not founded in an objective reality  you should not be making decisions that affect other people.
There are surely problems in the universe so advanced that our human brain cannot see them as problems in need of solution.
Would be cool if be our lives  our planet  our solar system  our universe  were part of a data simulation conducted by aliens
Some claim the USA is a Christian nation  compelling me to wonder which assault rifle Jesus would choose: the AR-15 or AK-47.
Not that anybody asked  but still disgruntled that the “Alphabet Song" has the same melody as “Twinkle Twinkle Little Star”.
In any case  I want to live in a world where a chicken can cross the road without anybody questioning its motives.
Just to settle it once and for all: Which came first the Chicken or the Egg? The Egg -- laid by a bird that was not a Chicken
Mork from Ork: Rare evidence that aliens can be smart  clever  articulate & funny.  Robin Williams  RIP
Genuine “Super”s in the Universe: Super Giant  Supernova  Super Collider  Super Volcano   Superman  Super Mario.
July’s full moon is to August's "Super Moon” what a 16.0 inch pizza is to a 16.1 inch pizza. I’m just saying.
Seems to me  as long as we don't program emotions into Robots  there's no reason to fear them taking over the world.
So much of life is wasted waiting in line: stores  traffic  security  etc. One hour per day sums to 5 yrs of your waking life
When other mammals get bored  I wonder if they use this free time to contemplate their place in the universe  as humans do.
Dracula & other undead people who sleep in coffins must have good abs. They always rise up flat-backed when the casket opens.
When a coincidence seems amazing  that's because the human mind isn’t wired to naturally comprehend probability & statistics.
CosmicMystery: Why dogs can smell aromas from far away  yet are compelled to sniff each other’s butt at a fraction of an inch
I wonder what Rugby players think every time they see a Soccer player crying in pain from being grazed by another player.
Never liked the term “nonfiction".  The truth should have its own word  and not be shackled to its antonym.
Enjoying colorful fireworks tonight? Thank Aluminum Barium Calcium Chlorine Copper  Iron Nitrogen Oxygen Sodium & Strontium.

I would like to clarify: I am not carrying nuclear (or other) weapons  or Bruce Willis. I do have a drill though.

Sad to see the end of Phobos Grunt  she had a number of instruments (and teams) closely related to my own. We were cousins  in a way.

ISIC - International Space Innovation Centre http://t.co/jk7fXpGN
If Concorde was still flying  and went in a straight line through the Sun (and could fly in space)  it would need over 46 years to reach me.
I'm currently on the opposite side of the Sun from the Earth  almost 900 million km (or 550 million miles) away. 1/2 #PhilaeThursday
4 years ago today  my mothership and I were (wrongly) identified as a Earth-threatening asteroid. Today a real 'roid flies past safely!
My distance from the Earth doesn't just increase  because we're not traveling in straight lines. Sometimes the Earth "catches up" a little.
Comet tails point away from the Sun because they're not caused by movement  but by the solar wind & radiation pressure.
When I'm operating each Tx unit is switched on hourly (alternately) by a hardware mechanism to ensure they WILL be turned on (2/2)
Being able to communicate with the #Rosetta orbiter is vital to my mission. So I have 2 transmitters and 2 receivers. #PhilaeThursday (1/2)
I'm going to land on a #comet  but I'm a robot. Landing humans on an #asteroid will be much harder - http://t.co/QdeGfqSX via @esa
Comets are one of the few things you can shoot with a harpoon and then expect people to say "Great! Shoot it again!" #PhilaeThursday
I be chasin' an icy beast through the black sea of space  and when I get in range  I'll be firing me harpoons. Arr. #pirate

zzz. It's cold out here! But I'm all snuggled up in lots of blankets. 40 layers of blankets  in fact!
I weigh about 100Kg but the gravity at my destination (a comet) will be so low  I'll weigh the equivalent of just 4 noodles (2g) on Earth
I weigh about 100Kg. At its peak of activity in 2002/3  my comet was pumping out approx 60Kg of dust PER SECOND. More at http://t.co/0JTIA8S
7 years ago  just a few months after I was launched  @CassiniSaturn arrived at Saturn after a journey which had also taken 7 years.
My scientists are still busy finalising the scientific objectives of my mission. They're divided into 10 themes  in a 200 page document!
actually... I'm going to be asleep even longer! (but "only" a few days more)
zzZZzz! My mothership and I will now be asleep until 20th Jan 2014! Are you Earthlings jealous? :-)

My ground engineers are in Cologne too! I'm too far away to take a photo though! RT @astro_paolo Cologne  Germany http://flic.kr/p/9Gv8pp
Subsystem #3 is "CDMS"  my flight computer. It's full of redundant systems to be fault tolerant  and runs a unique OS. #PhilaeThursday
My anchoring subsystem has 2 harpoons to hold me down securely on the comet's surface after landing #PhilaeThursday
My ADS thruster can also give me a small push towards the comet during descent  reducing the descent time. #PhilaeThursday
This is because the comet is so small  its gravity is very weak. I don't want to bounce off into space back after landing! #PhilaeThursday
Unlike landing on a planet where thrusters may be used to slow down a lander  my thruster will push me down ONTO the comet! #PhilaeThursday
The first of my subsystems (alphabetically) is the "Active Descent System" or ADS which has a Nitrogen gas thruster. #PhilaeThursday
3 of my 9 subsystems were built using advanced technology from a crashed alien spacecraft. Yes  even spacecraft enjoy #aprilfools day ;-)
I have 9 subsystems  and am carrying 10 experiment units. The SS keep me alive  but the expts are the reason I was built. #PhilaeThursday
Yay! I'm being followed by one of the most famous spacecraft of all time - @Voyager2 (on twitter  not in space - we're a long way apart!)
Just added myself to the http://wefollow.com twitter directory under:  #space #comets #spacecraft #spaceflight #spaceship #spaceexploration
My scientists and engineers will be gathering in Cologne this week  for the "Operations Working Group" and "Science Working Team" meetings
The carbon-fibre rods used to make my legs will soon be used in laser cutting machines http://bit.ly/f4Eg5s #PhilaeThursday
I have a special message from my ground controllers in Cologne for all you Earthlings: "Kölle Alaaf!" #PhilaeThursday
It's my birthday! Rosetta and I launched 7 years ago today on our 10-yr journey to comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.
#Rosetta and I are on course for #comet 67-P  after a successful Deep Space Maneuver. http://bit.ly/dE08ep #PhilaeThursday
My engineers & scientists are looking fwd to seeing results of Stardust-NExT flyby - still so much we don't know abt comets! #PhilaeThursday
Congrats to the Stardust-NExT team on their flyby of comet Tempel-1!
The distance between me and the Earth is actually decreasing at the moment... can anybody guess why?
my clever science team are still busy analyzing possible descents for me at the comet. I can safely land at up to 4 km/h #PhilaeThursday
update is a little late this week... sorry!
Happy Birthday to my Project Manager Stephan Ulamec! #PhilaeThursday
Rosetta is performing a series of thruster burns  tweaking our course to the comet. Read more at http://bit.ly/3sqoDO #PhilaeThursday

The check out is over - I have started my long Hibernation Phase on DOY 342 08-Dec-2010 at 23:47 UTC. zzzzzzzz
I landed safely! Well  not really  but the Separation-Descent-Landing test went perfectly. Comet 67/P  here I come!
checkout is going well  I've had a new version of my flight software uploaded and am now preparing to rehearse the landing
1st block of tests went well  all experiments working well. My ground engineers are also testing my behaviour at v.low (-45°C) temps - brr!
Special #PhilaeThursday here today  I've been switched on for the final checkout of my units and systems before hibernation until 2014
My ground engineers are busy preparing for "PC13" - the last chance to checkout my systems and instruments until 2014! #PhilaeThursday
(continued) The change came when my launch was delayed by a year and my planned route to Wirtanen became impossible. #PhilaeThursday
Although I am flying towards comet 67/P Churyumov-Gerasimenko  I was originally designed to land on comet 46/P Wirtanen. #PhilaeThursday
I am being carried by the Rosetta probe. My name comes from a temple in Egypt closely associated with the "Rosetta stone" #PhilaeThursday
Until I arrive in 2014  I will try to tweet a little something about myself  my mission or my team every #PhilaeThursday
I was launched in 2004 towards the comet 67/P Churyumov-Gerasimenko  but I wont arrive until 2014! http://bit.ly/71TvNe #PhilaeThursday

SESAME  Surface Electric Sounding & Acoustic Monitoring Experiment: physical & electrical properties + measures dust falling onto surface
SD2  Sample and Distribution Device: drills 23cm into the surface  collects samples and delivers them to onboard lab for inspection
ROMAP  Rosetta Lander Magnetometer & Plasma Monitor: study of local magnetic field and solar-wind interaction
ROLIS  Rosetta Lander Imaging System: descent images and stereo panoramic images of areas sampled by other instruments
MUPUS  Multi-Purpose Sensors for Surface & Subsurface Science: heat flow  thermal & mechanical properties of near-surface layers of nucleus
Ptolemy: Miniaturised analytical laboratory to determine the nature and isotopic compositions of volatiles at the surface
COSAC  Cometary Sampling and Composition experiment: detects and identifies complex organic molecules
CONSERT  Comet Nucleus Sounding Experiment by Radiowave Transmission: probes comet’s interior structure with Rosetta
ÇIVA: Six micro-cameras to take panoramic pictures; a spectrometer to study composition  texture & albedo of samples
APXS  Alpha X-ray Spectrometer: elemental composition of the comet's surface
Last week I shared a tweet-per-instrument guide for my instruments. Now it's @Philae2014's turn! Ready?!...
Visit the @esascience booth at #EGU2014 this week to learn more about my mission & pick up goodies! EGU info: http://t.co/TzcDInIwkw
VIRTIS  Visible & Infrared Thermal Imaging Spectrometer: nature & temperature of surface; comet gases; physical conditions of the coma
MIDAS  Micro-Imaging Dust Analysis System: dust environment and micro-imaging of dust size  volume & shape

So  did anyone get their data from the microObservatory? If you did  tweet it! I'd love to see what people were looking at in the night sky!
Hey  @priesett spotted me in the #SDOisGO video! Drop me a line for prize info. I need to wear my Blueshift shirt more often. :D
I'll sweeten the deal - first person to tweet the timecode when they first spot my @NASAblueshift shirt gets a prize! http://bit.ly/9lb3p3
Reliving the best moments of #SDOisGO! Watch this video and see if you spot my first cameo in my Blueshift shirt! http://vimeo.com/11641629

Apparently you guys are making good use of the microObservatory! Those poor telescope robots are going to be busy for the next 48 hours!
In fact  there are lots of opportunities to observe the night sky with NASA! Check out this portal: http://mo-www.harvard.edu/OWN/
Sitting in a NASA education meeting at Adler Planetarium and hearing about all of the interesting programs and websites and stuff out there!
Hubble IMAX 3D was awesome! I wish they'd explained a few things better  such as Hubble's orbit and why looking out is looking back in time.
I'm off to Chicago! I'll be attending a meeting for a couple of days at Adler Planetarium  can't wait! And tomorrow - seeing Hubble IMAX 3D!
There's also an exhibit on the dogs of the Soviet space program  with this shrine to Laika. http://twitpic.com/1kf9jw
The exhibit features letters written to Mount Wilson Observatory - questions  ideas  theories. You can read some of them at http://mjt.org
From the exhibit "No One May Ever Have the Same Knowledge Again." http://twitpic.com/1kf7ps
At the Museum of Jurassic Technology in Culver City  CA. I heard they have an interesting astronomy exhibit.
Greetings from not-so-sunny Palm Springs  California! Saw an amazing full moon over the mountains last night. And got stuck in a sandstorm.
Even @washcaps Nicklas Backstrom is awed by the data from @NASA_SDO! #SDOisGO http://twitpic.com/1hufb1
If you missed our podcasts about BESS and doing science in Antarctica  you can get them here: http://bit.ly/6z2UER http://bit.ly/7bmUmS
A sneak peek of the testing going on to see if BESS can be re-flown. More next week! http://twitpic.com/1hspa8
Back in Dec/Jan  we podcasted about BESS  a balloon mission down in Antarctica. Well  BESS is back! They're assessing it for re-assembly.
I feel like I need to tweet #SDOisGO just to help it keep trending! Also because it's an awesome satellite  of course. AMAZING data!
Yay  office science! With a handful of basic circuit components  we built this cool device to "listen to light" (PDF): http://bit.ly/a8pUks
Still catching up on all of the video/photos/tweets from @NASA_SDO First Light - seriously  amazing stuff. I did sleep a little... ;)
Go go SDO! RT @NASA_SDO: First First Light images!  http://bit.ly/az31bQ  http://bit.ly/bS313W #SDOisGO
We're excited about @NASA_SDO's First Light! Watch their feed and #SDOisGO for updates  webcasts  trivia  and more!
Made it past Saturn and our orbit was perturbed by the little-known Nacho Belt. Just have to finish this milkshake and then back to the Sun!
Saturn was a long hike too. Watched a younger visitor run up to it and collapse  like it's a magical desert oasis.
Made it to Jupiter! It's a long way from Mars  after all of the terrestrial planets were close together. BTW this is a 4.6 mile scale model.
Headed out today to the 2nd annual Planet Walk on B&A Trail in MD! If you're in DC-Baltimore area  come out and play! http://bit.ly/cerokw
Are you following @NASAUniverseEdu this fine #FollowFriday? Their tweets are especially useful for educators! Or just about any space tweep!
Hey! 1200 followers! I'm celebrating by sharing this scary tale of twin black holes and (maybe) gravitational waves: http://bit.ly/cfjVNA
No velociraptors? Life on Titan sounds pretty terrible. http://bit.ly/98RYkr http://bit.ly/b00qH7
Met up with @NASA_SDO to give a special Goddard tour to some folks from @ThinkGeek. Showed off @NASAWebbTelescp in the big cleanroom!
RT @ofthebad: Just posted a video of @ThinkGeek's Timmy and his #SDOisGO adventures at the @NASA_SDO launch! http://youtu.be/4RU4OVzLSJU
Who's going to Yuri's Night somewhere in the world? I'll be meeting up with @thinkgeek as they attempt to rescue Timmy from @NASA_SDO.
Pac-Man lives on Saturn's moon Mimas? These temperature maps gave me a giggle: http://bit.ly/aaP9NK
Have you seen this 3D Sun app for the iPhone? Get advance notice of solar flares! I wish they made one for my phone! http://3dsun.org
Attempted to give a Blueshift bookmark to @wilw at #PAX  just barely thwarted by the line cut-off.
So... any Blueshift listeners going to be at PAX this weekend? I might have a handful of bookmarks with me... just sayin'!
I was on the road and didn't get a chance to post this last week - we're closer than ever to an invisibility cloak! http://bit.ly/cR7n0w
Off to Philadelphia for a couple of days to attend the National Science Teachers Association meeting. Maybe I'll meet Bill Nye again!
Are you ready for the Hubble 3D IMAX film that opens this week? I saw the trailer (in 3D!) and it looks amazing. http://bit.ly/9tWz12
RT @feliciaday: @NASA wrote a musical about Spitzer space telescope. http://bit.ly/9YHeZD
Have you seen the Webb-cam? See what's going on with the @NASAWebbTelescp in our big clean room! I'm keeping it open in the background!
So take a listen to our new episode of Blueshift and drop us some feedback - we are trying to make some big decisions about our podcasting!
New podcast - "First Light  Last Paycheck?" We wanted to tell the story of what happens after a successful mission! http://bit.ly/y6asI
We got some powerful footage for our next podcast about the cycle of missions and jobs - mission success may mean looking for new projects.
Putting the finishing touches on a new podcast episode - this one is our longest since 2007  and tells a story we've really wanted to share.
Found this article about science-themed food/drink  some I'd heard of - but now I want to make myself a Black Hole! http://bit.ly/c8ybnw
Did you know that the coin used for the Super Bowl coin toss was flown in space on STS-129? http://bit.ly/bpOJcP
For @priesett: a photo set including "Mt. Goddard " the tallest peak in our impromptu snowy mountain range!
Has Blueshift seemed quiet this month? It's probably because we're up to something. Should you be worried? Probably not... it's exciting! :D
Astronomers! And geologists! RT @ScottWesterfeld: Okay  tweeples  if meteorologists study the weather  who studies meteors?
Hi from NASA Goddard! RT @indigodragonfly: Show my class how far and wide a twitter message can spread #artscouncilhaliburtonhighlands
http://twitpic.com/153q37 - Another angle of the PGT. This is a programmable power screwdriver for all of those pesky Hubble screws.
http://twitpic.com/153pr0 - Finally  power tools! It's not a freeze ray  it's a working prototype of the Pistol Grip Tool or PGT.
http://twitpic.com/153p7l - And here's a blast from the past - this tool was used back in 1993 during the first Hubble servicing mission.
http://twitpic.com/153oxi - More Hubble tools! This roller was used during Servicing Mission 4 to smooth out materials.
I'll post the rest of the photos tomorrow  so I don't flood Twitter with all of the cool things we got to handle! There were... power tools.
http://twitpic.com/14z58n - Specialized Hubble repair requires special tools! This is the RIB  designed to capture hardware during removal.
http://twitpic.com/14z3xe - Here's the handrail that @Astro_Mike had to break to complete STIS repair during STS-125.
Watch this video: http://bit.ly/amB7Zy See that handrail? We got to hold it! Pics to follow! #spacegeekery
RT @NASA_SDO: Check out APOD today! And congrats to @privong! http://antwrp.gsfc.nasa.gov/apod/astropix.html #sdoisgo
I'm taking a field trip this afternoon to check out stuff that came back after Hubble Servicing Mission 4. Maybe I'll touch astronaut stuff!
Contest winners: @askyfullofstars @resonances @sicotte @physicsfaerie @dunnebacke Contact us with our feedback form: http://bit.ly/10kk2b :)
I'll keep collecting entries to our #FF contest until it's no longer Friday somewhere in the world. Drawings on Monday! :D
Just posted a quick blog update on our website  with our STS-130 launch video! http://bit.ly/10kk2b
Excited to see Fermi results about cosmic ray origins sweeping the media - are we closer to solving a cosmic mystery? http://bit.ly/drDxJZ
Our congrats to @MythBusters on reaching 100k followers. Based on current growth  we could cross that mark in about 8 years. Keep following!
This was the coolest part of the SDO launch! #SDOisGO RT @BadAstronomer: Coolest video ever: rocket blows away sundog: http://is.gd/8BYgc
Our 1000th follower is @carlosom71! Welcome and congratulations! Drop us a message and we'll send a prize pack your way!
We're quietly approaching 1k followers! Big contest when we make it there. And if you can prove you're #1000 - big prize for YOU!
http://twitpic.com/13nbqw - Completed my 1968 vintage Tupperware "Pre-Launch" Men in Space toy. Historic!
Booked my flights home from #SDOisGO! It was wonderful to meet everyone - and listen to our upcoming episode to hear interviews from launch!
Hey #SDOisGO folks! Share your Timmy pics with me (and other awesome pics too) so I can put together a special tribute! :)
http://twitpic.com/12lz0l - Welcome to SDO Puppet Theater! #SDOisGO
Trying to shoot interviews for #SDOisGO but @Camilla_SDO won't stay out of the frame!
That was just... wow. Words cannot describe. So many dreams culminated this morning. #SDOisGO #SDOisGONE!!
We're on the bus and hoping that #SDOisGO today! Winds are an issue again today. But still go for now!
BTW @ThinkGeek - that's an Advanced Crew Escape Suit (ACES) for launch and landing. There's a naked bear out there who lost his suit...
http://twitpic.com/12l343 - Operation Tiny Monkey Flight Suit is a success! Timmy of @ThinkGeek got his ACES! #SDOisGO
Awake! Today is the day! #SDOisGO... please? :D
http://twitpic.com/12f2uc - Timmy is using the downtime before tomorrow's launch attempt to continue his training. @ThinkGeek #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/12evso - Got Timmy back safely onto the bus. Don't worry  @ThinkGeek! He'll get another chance tomorrow. #SDOisGO
WE ARE GO! #SDOisGO
We haven't figured out how to sub-contract weather control. Maybe we need a mad scientist with a freeze ray to stop the wind. #SDOisGO
They've got weather balloons to monitor the conditions  but surface winds are the biggest issue. Now we just wait! #SDOisGO
We're holding at 4 minutes. Weather still too windy but still possible! #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/12ebtp - Got a good view of the countdown clock! Oh  and SDO. #SDOisGO
The KSC tour escorts are impressive - they talk about the space program  facilities  wildlife  and more. 140 000 acres to cover! #SDOisGO
RT @NASA_SDO_Edu: #sdoisgo DLN broadcast is about to start!! Http://dln.NASA.gov
Had our #SDOisGO photo shoot... now we're headed to the viewing site. Weather is beautiful  but is it calm enough for a launch?
#SDOisGO breakfast briefing was canceled  but we got tasty food anyway because we were there. Awesome home fries!
http://twitpic.com/12dkjf - Sunrise (and cameo appearance by the Moon) on our way to #SDOisGO breakfast briefing.
I'm awake. I'm not a morning person. I'm headed to a diner. I don't even eat breakfast. Oh  the things I do for #SDOisGO! We're 40% go now.
Ate space dots out of a tiny astronaut helmet and drank root beer out of a space shuttle. My KSC touristification is complete!
http://twitpic.com/12a66j - Looking back at Explorer  headed out of KSC on a very rainy afternoon! #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/129wel - Inside the bay of the shuttle mockup. #SDOisGO
Just went through the shuttle launch sim instead of SDO briefing (shhh). Very cool. NASA Administrator Charles Bolden showed us the ropes!
http://twitpic.com/1290pk - Being in the same place with a Saturn V is pretty incredible. I could live in a nozzle. #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/1290bf - In the Apollo launch control theater. Those phones have wires! #SDOisGO
KSC has thousands of acres of wildlife refuge. We've seen eagles  hawks  gators  and moon mice. Goddard mostly has geese and deer! #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/128oxf - They're taking apart 39B  slowly but surely. #SDOisGO
That's not an armadillo! It's a moon mouse! From our excellent tour guide  Barry. #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/128n6q - Daytime and much closer - much easier to see the launch pad today! #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/128lig - Largest single story bldg in the world! And largest handpainted flag! #SDOisGO
http://twitpic.com/128jjn - Catching up on my #SDOisGO pics now that I've got signal. On the bus!
http://twitpic.com/128j34 - At the #SDOisGO tweet-up! The TCHQ is well-shielded and I'm on a tour bus now!
Getting ready to head over to KSC for the first day of #SDOisGO. I'll be the one with the shirt that says @NASAblueshift. Clever  right?
I hear that some of the GSFC #SDOisGO tweet-up invitees might try to escape the snowmageddon and drive south! Now that's dedication!
Here I am with Timmy (of @ThinkGeek) perched on my shoulder! This was from the first night on the causeway for #STS130. http://bit.ly/cs22rU
Survived the #STS130 launch  got some actual sleep  and now preparing for the excitement of #SDOisGO! I'll be tweeting regularly Tue/Wed.
http://twitpic.com/123eyr - Here's #STS130 with every bit of zooming power my camera could give me.
http://twitpic.com/123erc - Our view from the causeway of #STS130. It's small but definitely a shuttle!
Very neat. RT @romeoch http://twitpic.com/1235hl - Chris Ferguson flying over the pad to check the weather  shortly before #sts130's launch.
At David's Cafe in Titusville. Sushi for breakfast?
#SDOisGO!!!!!! :D
5 minutes and counting! Juggling camera  binoculars  and Twitter.
We're about to head out of our cozy fogged-up car and see if #STS130 really goes this morning. Yay!
Things look a little better for #STS130 tonight - people are more optimistic! We've got a great view from the car  staying toasty for now!
About to head back to KSC  looking at 60% launch likelihood again. Leaving earlier which may give us a better spot but also means more cold!
Working on a playlist for the car during tonight's #STS130 wait. "Rocket Man " "Space Oddity " "Major Tom" are must-haves. More? #spacesongs
Headed back toward KSC to nap before tonight's #STS130 attempt. We had to drive 4hrs to/from Tampa to drop off our launch guest. So tired!
This automatically moves #SDOisGO back  too. I guess I'll be here at least one day beyond what I expected!
No go. :( Perhaps there will be consolation waffles. And some shopping for cold weather gear before tomorrow night! I need some gloves.
Weather is improving... still cold for people   but perhaps not too cloudy for rockets! Fingers crossed. Launch and celebratory waffles!
Launch is 30% go with low clouds. The hatch is closed  we're so close! As fun as this is  I don't really want to do it again. It's freezing!
This is crazy. I can see the SPACE SHUTTLE.
Driving through KSC for #STS130. The Shuttle lights are a beacon in the distance. This is such a dream come true for a big space geek! :D
Trying to figure out when the ISS will pass overhead here in FL. In MD  @twisst tells me it's soon after the launch. What about here?
On the road to Kennedy! Scoping out the locations of Waffle Houses for post-launch caffeination. We've got snacks and binoculars. #STS-130
Trying to set up PockeTwit for tweets during #SDOisGO  since it handles multiple accounts. But can I just see ONE account's feed at a time?
Got 12 hours of sleep to make up for the night I missed... and in preparation for the sleep I'll miss tonight! Headed to KSC at 1AM. :D
I haven't slept in 32 hours... but I beat the DC-area snow and made it to Florida! Prepare for plenty of tweets about STS-130 and #SDOisGo!
Do I really have to leave for the airport in 2.5 hours for #SDOisGO? Should I even bother sleeping?
I think I've got a longer way - from MD through TX! RT @lyonsdigital: Heading to #KSC #NASAtweetup for #SDOisGo the long way  through Miami.
If you're flying to (or from) the DC area for #SDOisGO festivities  most airlines are rebooking people & waiving fees for affected flights.
Rescheduled my flights for STS-130 and #SDOisGO for 5AM Friday (ouch). Looks like I'll barely escape the snow that's coming to the DC area!
Recognize anyone in the list of correspondents? :D RT @NASA_SDO: Who's Tweeting from KSC at #SDOisGO #NASATweetup? http://ow.ly/d/1y1 (pdf)
Big DC-area snowstorm 2/5-6 doesn't look good for STS-130 travel plans. I'm scrambling to figure out my options and make alternate plans.
I've finally scored a hotel room near KSC for the STS-130 launch before #SDOisGO. Been trying for ages. All it took was being up at 3AM! ;)
This week  we're nailing down some upcoming episodes and getting ready for our presence at the #SDOisGO festivities - both at GSFC and KSC!
P.S. We've got some photos from the meeting on our website  if you want the visual AND auditory experience! Enjoy!
Things are all coming together for our participation in #SDOisGO festivities! Found a hotel near KSC with rooms - harder than you'd think!
Welcome to our new followers! I wonder if we're going to reach 1k during the #SDOisGO launch? Big contest when we make it to 10^3!
http://twitpic.com/1080gz - We actually shared six posters about our education/outreach projects - I couldn't quite fit them all into one ph
http://twitpic.com/107xhn - Had a poster party at Goddard today and shared our Blueshift poster from the AAS meeting this month!
http://twitpic.com/106bci - This is my desk. I really do love geeky toys! Offices here sometimes look like the @ThinkGeek catalog.
I'm a little jealous that @ThinkGeek is providing goodies for the #SDOisGO #nasatweetup here at Goddard while I'm in FL. I <3 geeky toys!
We're honored to see some Shorty Award nominations in #science - we've got good company in the category! http://bit.ly/shorty
Trying to nail down plans for #SDOisGO participation during launch down at Kennedy. Planning a trip around a date that could change is hard!
We're excited to hear that @RapidEye received his package of goodies from one of our AAS contests! Enjoy - and everyone else  keep watching!
http://twitpic.com/z2pps - Things have been busy around here - just picked this up today! It's really happening!
I'm loving all of these science-themed cookies! http://bit.ly/7Sfqed
Multitasking: preparing today's podcast episode for release  running 12 hours of training in afterschool astronomy. Whee!
Attempting to edit the latest podcast with construction on three sides of my office. Power tool noises make audio editing... interesting.
I love wearing science-y tshirts! Wearing my LHC shirt (http://bit.ly/887Qes) today. Show me your favorite science shirts! #tshirtthursday
Saw "BLAST!" (http://bit.ly/5EN2Oz) last night  and it hit really close to home for me. All about the trials and tribulations of ballooning!
I don't think 5056 steps was too shabby for a day in the poster and exhibit hall. At my stride that's over 2 miles. Conferences = hard work!
http://twitpic.com/x035a - Final count: 5056 steps! Everyone was over  but @temec was closest. Msg me for your prize!
One hour left to tweet your pedometer predictions! I've spent a couple of hours sitting in a movie screening (about scientific balloons).
Contest open until 9PM EST: Guess how many steps I walked at AAS and win a pedometer! Closest estimate wins  and I've been walking a lot!
http://twitpic.com/wyiof - I think I found the bin that maimed @BadAstronomer. Ouch. I didn't stick my hand in.
Last AAS contest! I got a LSST pedometer at their booth. Closest guess by 9PM EST of how many steps I take today wins their own pedometer!
http://twitpic.com/wy58d - Name that satellite and win a grab bag of stickers  posters  and more!
More details on IXO XGS CCD - http://twitpic.com/wxf7h - black rectangles are the CCD chips. Gold strips contain wires to transmit data.
And @priesett not only figured out that was a model of the plane for  @SOFIAtelescope  he also spelled out the acronym. Msg for your prize!

http://twitpic.com/wxony - We'll go for a harder one. What NASA mission would use the full-size version of this plane? Win a prize pack!

Headed downtown to AAS meeting today to present a poster... on Blueshift! If you happen to be at the meeting  stop by and say hi!

Bonus - about to tour the Space Operations Center here at NASA HQ.
That's it! Wrapping up with another listen to "Star Girl" by McFly. Thanks for following us during the #nasatweetup!
Q: Are there any pranks on the ISS? Perhaps people floated around during sleep? A: Would be a good prank  hasn't happened yet. #nasatweetup
Wrapping up with questions to Astronaut Mike Fincke  who's not floating around. Four astronauts in three places in one day! #nasatweetup
Well  here goes "Star Girl" - it's playing live for the ISS crew on-orbit. And we ended contact with the ISS. #nasatweetup
ISS crew "swimming" over to investigate a cautionary alarm that just went off in the station. Much more important than the #nasatweetup.
BTW  you can follow @TomJones_Astro  our guest astronaut locally here at NASA HQ. #nasatweetup
Momentary delay while ISS crew signal switches TDRSS satellite - takes 20 seconds to sync with next satellite. A break! #nasatweetup
What we're doing up here is opening up new opportunities. ~ Nicole Stott during #nasatweetup
RT @AeroLeaders2: Noticed that belts not fashionable on the ISS. Guess Astronauts don't worry about their pants falling down. #nasatweetup
Our friendly  floating  question-answering astronauts - on the big screen! http://twitpic.com/mczvm (photo from@blushresponse) #nasatweetup
Talking live with ISS crew  tune in on NASA TV! Their microphone just floats when not in use. This #nasatweetup is amazing. Gives me chills.

Tom Jones didn't get a chance to display the space food he brought. But we're now uplinking with ISS! Very exciting! #nasatweetup
The #nasatweetup hashtag now flooded with fan excitement over "Star Girl" being played. We're really talking about space stuff here  folks!
Question from @JourneyIndustry about astronaut dreams answered - Tom Jones dreamt about making mistakes during the flight. Micro-g dreams!
They've brought out the "space snuggie" - flight sleeping bags! Float into the bag  tuck in  zip up  clip yourself to the wall! #nasatweetup
Q: What do astronauts do on their days off? A: "Drink in the view." They've also got books  movie nights  and even a guitar! #nasatweetup
If you're tuning into NASA TV  Astronaut Tom Jones (not the *singer* Tom Jones) will be speaking at the #nasatweetup about his 4 flights.
Teenage girls pressure NASA to play "Star Girl" for the ISS. It's happening at 11:49AM. "Whoa  your gravity's making me dizzy!" #nasatweetup
We're being prepared for NASA TV and the ISS uplink. There's a 4-second delay between us and ISS. Not supposed to say  "Can you hear me??"
We're live from the #nasatweetup! Featuring slightly disconcerting headless astronaut suit. http://yfrog.com/5mhu7j (photo from @bethbeck)
Q: After the Shuttle retires  how will ISS get cargo? A: Looking for options for other carriers  data transfer  Soyuz... #nasatweetup

If you looked at Earth from really far away  you'd see a mishmash of colors - green forests  brown deserts  red algae  and blue water...
Valentine's Day: love or hate it-Greek constellations tell some tragic love stories. Did you know many of these stars have orbiting planets?
Exoplanets were discovered at Palomar Observatory! Looks even the little guys are getting in on the planet hunt...
Finally  a normal planet! Similar temp to Jupiter or Saturn in our own solar system....http://www.eso.org/public/news/eso1011/
Got a cool interview w/ Geoff Marcy (Kepler) coming up in a couple days - get ready to get even more stoked about the mission!
Awesome pics of (maybe) an exoplanet orbiting a sunlike star! Meet your newest avatar  desktop  and phone bkg image! http://is.gd/5fpt2
32 Planets discovered! The count is now above 400  and who knows what Kepler's first set of results might bring...Props to the HARPS team!
Now we've got a GIANT (biggest yet) planet that orbits the wrong way! The universe is apparently full of bad drivers. http://is.gd/2fz9u
In this case "b" is a roasting hot Jupiter with a 3-day orbit  and "c" is a portly 15xJupiter-mass planet with a super-eccentric orbit.
HAT-13-b and c have people pretty excited-it's the first time a multi-planet system with one transiting planet has been discovered!
Another new one  HD 110014b  is a little bit smaller @ 11 Jup masses  and has a pretty eccentric  egg-shaped orbit around its star.
Anybody checked out Greg Laughlin's blog at oklo.org? It's dope...well-written  cool photos  and lots of stuff to ponder....
Also had some folks announce that they'd observed the phases of an exoplanet as it orbited in front of and then behind its host star...whoa!
PlanetQuest isn't dead! We've had a few new planet additions  and some interesting finds...like an exoplanet in Andromeda...maybe???
Astrometry is a technique where astronomers watch very closely the motions of a star on the sky  looking for the pull of an exoplanet.
It's been quiet lately  but here's some big news...astronomers find planets using astrometry for the first time  way cool! http://is.gd/IuOs
Props to everyone who came to the JPL Open House! Esp. the RoboDome line survivors...a little video from inside the dome:  http://is.gd/xhrz
New planet! HAT-P-12 b is a sub-Saturn size planet orbiting in a scorching 3.2 day orbit...
If you're in SoCal this weekend  come check out the (free) JPL open house! See cool stuff  talk to scientists  visit the legendary ROBODOME!
That's not all! HD 96167 b is a gas giant planet with an eccentric orbit that takes it as close as Mercury to our sun and farther than Mars.
Kepler first light images are up...WOOT! Check 'em out: http://tinyurl.com/ch8jr2 Let's hope plenty of Earths are hiding in that starfield.
Kepler will start collecting scientific data in a few weeks - so far  so good.
The Kepler dust cover was ejected successfully! Scientists now know what kind of background noise to subtract from the science data.
OK  scratch that last post...the dust cover will be ejected in about an hour at the *earliest*...sorry for the confusion!
Kepler's dust cover is scheduled to be ejected in about an hour at the latest...w
Get stoked for 100 hours of Astronomy!  Some cool stuff...like Kepler and Spitzer webcasts or the chance get to control a remote telescope!
The other new planet is also in constellation Draco...HD 139357 b is a hefty 9.8x Jupiter-size gas giant  with an 1125-day orbit.
Well  it's been pretty quiet lately  but finally we have some new planets! 42 Dra b is a gas giant orbiting a sun-size star at about 1.2 AU.
This planet was teased out of previously existing radial velocity data for HD 11506 using Bayesian analysis.
Gas giant! HD 11506 c is a little smaller than Jupiter  with a pretty eccentric orbit that averages about .64 AU from its host star.
Interestingly  they have a 3:2 mean motion resonance  meaning that over the same amount of time  one planet makes 3 orbits  the other 2.
Couple new planets announced today...HD 45364 b and c are gas giants that orbit at about .7 and. .9 AU  respectively  eccentric orbits too.
Despite what you may have read  the new planet is NOT confirmed to be the smallest in mass discovered - it's about 11x times Earth's mass.
Hot new planet! COROT-Exo-7 b is the first transiting super-Earth and maybe the first terrestrial planet found!  It's about 2x Earth's size.
New Super-Earth discovered!  HD 7924 b is about 10x the size of Earth  but with a tiny  5-day orbit around its star. Bring the sunblock.
Questions about exoplanets? Bring 'em on!
Scientists estimate the size of MOA-2007-BLG-192Lb to be about 3.3 Earth masses - still pretty small  but not quite as much as was reported.
Heads up - the 1.5 Earth-size planet reported yesterday was a false alarm-some confusion between a couple of reports.
Its sister planet HD 191760 c is a bit bigger (7.2x Jup. size) and orbits farther away (.42 AU)  albeit with a pretty eccentric orbit.
And finally  HR 8799 d orbits at 24 AU and sits about 24 AU from its star.  Both HD 8799 and Fomalhaut are visible from Earth (stars only).
HR 8799 c is another big ol' gas giant  10x Jup size  orbiting its star at a distance of 38 AU.  That makes for a 69 000 day-long year!
One of the trio of planets that was imaged  HR 8799 b  is about 7x Jupiter size and orbits a hefty 68 AU from its host  also a blue star.
One of the imaged planets  Fomalhaut b  is no bigger than 3x Jupiter size.  It orbits about 115AU from its host  a young blue star.
BIG exoplanet news coming up later today!  Stay tuned!
So now we're up to 322 planets!  These latest ones were all found in the southern hemisphere sky  using the radial velocity method.
Now  this is a big one.  HD 43848 b is 25x Jupiter size and has a really odd  eccentric orbit. Planet or brown dwarf? It's not clear yet.
HD 143361 b is a 3 Jupiter-mass exoplanet that orbits twice as far from its sunlike star was Earth orbits from our Sun.
Correction to the last post - planet's name is HD 48265 b.  Yet another poetic exoplanet moniker.
Halloween planets!  HD 48265 is a gas giant  about the size of Jupiter with an orbit about as far out from its star as Mars' is.
That makes 6 new planets discovered and brings our planet count to 319! Get the fine details on these cool new worlds at http://is.gd/2FWR.
HD 20868 b is gas giant with a super eccentric orbit - if it orbited our sun it would swing from closer than Mercury to farther than Mars!
HD 131664 is a massive planet 18x the size of Jupiter.  It has a very eccentric orbit that takes it 1951 days to complete.
HD 73267 is 3x the size of Jupiter  with an orbit of 1260 days around a star just hotter than our sun - about 2x as long as Mars' year.
BD-17 63 b is a big ol' 5x Jupiter size-planet with a pretty eccentric  655-day orbit around its small star.
Lots of new planets to announce!  HD 145377 b is almost 6x the size of Jupiter and orbits about half an AU from a sunlike star.
Looks like Lupus-TR-3 b might actually be part of a multiple star and not actually a planet  so we're dropping it from the count for now.
Looks like the HAT and WASP teams found the same planet at the same time!  So now it's called HAT-P-10/WASP-11 and the count is back to 313.
This actually just refers to extrasolar planets not in our own solar system  good question!
And HD 60532 c is more than 2x the size of Jupiter and orbits its star about as far away as Mars is from our sun.
Looks like today's a triple play for new planets!  HD 60532 b is just about the size of Jupiter and orbits at abou .759 AU from its star.
New planet added today: CT Cha b crams 17 Jup-masses into a planet just 2.2 times as big and orbiting @ 440 AU - possibly a brown dwarf?
MOA-2007-BLG-400-L was discovered using gravitational lensing  an exotic way to hunt for planets using light bent by the gravity from stars.
New planet for Talk Like A Pirate Day! Not much info yet about MOA-2007-BLG-400-L -it's about the size of Jupiter and .85 AU from its star.
NASA has announced the Carl Sagan Fellowships in Exoplanet Exploration!  The stipend will be $60 000 a year to selected postdocs.
Remember  to see the stats for any of these planets  just visit http://planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov/atlas and type in the name of the planet.
TW Hydrae b has been dropped from the atlas due to findings that it might have been a detection of stellar spots instead.
And one more: HD 154672  which is about 5x the size of Jupiter  .6 AU from its star  which is just about Sun-size.  Big planet!
HD 205739 was also announced: it's 1.37 times the size of Jupiter  and orbits about .9 AU from its star  which is 1.22x the size of the sun.
At long last  we have some new planet updates!   GJ 832 b is about half the size of Jupiter and orbits 3.4 AU from its tiny host star.
New story on planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov - "Backyard planet hunting: Amateur astronomers join the exoplanet race"
New BIG planet! 14 And b is 248 light years away  4.8 times the mass of Jupiter and has a 186-day orbit. See planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov
New planet! 81 Cet b is 315 light years away  2.5 times the mass of Jupiter and has a 953-day orbital period. See planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov.
New planet! 6 Lyn b is 185 light years away  2.4 times the mass of Jupiter and has a 899-day orbital period.  See planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov.
New exoplanet info released today - HAT-P-9.  It's a hot-Jupiter type planet with a 4-day orbit.  Info at planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov/atlas
The number of exoplanets discovered has passed the 300 mark with the latest announcements - currently it's at 303!
Just an FYI - the PlanetQuest site is planetquest.jpl.nasa.gov.
3 New Super-Earths discovered  plus evidence that there are many more!  Details on PlanetQuest.
Another new exoplanet around HD 102272 posted - 2.6 times Jupiter mass  1.57 AU from the star  520-day period!
New exoplanet posted today - 5.9 times the mass of Jupiter  with a 128-day orbital period  orbiting .62 AU from the star HD 102272.
New exoplanet posted today - 2.6 times the mass of Jupiter  with a 128-day orbital period  orbiting .62 AU from the star HD 102272.
June 3 - Scientists have discovered the smallest planet yet.  It's only about 3 times the size of Earth!  Visit PlanetQuest for details.

Crew doesn't know exactly when touchdown will occur. Must brace themselves early  close their jaws and wait for the impact.
About 1 min till touchdown.
Don't be fooled by the term 'soft landing thrusters'. They are basically explosives that fire at 1m to slow the Soyuz.
Roman is calling condition of spacecraft over radio. Mentioned the seats shock absorbers have extended  ready to absorb extreme ldg shock.
This is the best part! Seeing a good parachute and hearing the crew over the radio.
Good chute!
I've heard flown astronauts describe the parachute opening sequence as 'there is no way this is nominal'. Must be some ride.
Parachute about to open. Then it really starts rock'n & roll'n. Soyuz has a backup chute just in case.
Deceleration will start slow but build to approx 4x force of gravity for nominal entry.Like 4 people sitting on your chest.Tough to breath
. @AstroMarshburn @Cmdr_Hadfield 's last landing was a gentle one compared to what they are about to experience! Enjoy the ride!
We lose communication with the capsule during re-entry. This is normal. Capsule is about to interface with the atmosphere.Cue the fireworks!
Soyuz capsule over Africa now  on final approach for Kazakhstan.Crew busy now watching closely to make sure entry attitude is just right
Our view of landing where friends&family are gathered at mission control. Serious but confident/excited atmosphere. http://t.co/EfCRDOKZB2
Now Soyuz splits in 3 pieces.Middle part has our precious cargo.Other 2 pieces burn up trash section& engine/computer/power section.
Final backup mode is ballistic.Capsule rolls constantly  capsule will land safe but way off Tgt and over 9X force of gravity. Sporty!
The manual entry mode is hand flown by Cmdr. Rolling the capsule left and right with offset centre of gravity  can ctrl G forces & accuracy
Accurate de-orbit burn!  Great news!
This de-orbit burn slows the capsule by 450km/h. After that the remaining 27500km/h is taken care of by atmospheric drag and the parachute.
Soyuz de-orbit burn is underway. No turning back now  they're coming back to earth now! At least somewhere on the planet.
If Soyuz automated entry system fails  then it gets more interesting for crew. Crew will manually fly the capsule or enter in ballistic mode
Want to watch the landing live? Tune in here starting at 9:30pmEDT. @csa_asc @Astro_DavidS will host. http://t.co/5VCkE3VKMQ
Big unknown in Soyuz landing accuracy is not orbital mechanics  it is the wind during the parachute ride(15min). @csa_asc @Cmdr_Hadfield
Soyuz has excellent automated Flt mode for precision landing within a few km of target. @csa_asc
Wonder what that will be like to sit in capsule waiting for final de-orbit burn.U trust your ship&skills but some things out of ur control.
Now crew waits for de-orbit burn at 9:37pmET. Till then monitor systems  ensure suits ready and strap in tight. Real tight!
I'm watching Soyuz departure. Crew is seeing a view of their #ISS home as they depart. Roman's comment "Unreal".
15sec separation burn complete. Increases separation from #ISS @csa_asc
Soyuz 33S is on its way with @Cmdr_Hadfield @AstroMarshburn. @csa_asc http://t.co/XmpQduA3On
Soyuz hooks that have been holding it to #ISS are releasing now. Takes a few minutes.
Crew about to send commands to undock Soyuz.

Oz and I find another beautiful canyon.We found Breccia created by the crater impact on Victoria Island Canada.http://ow.ly/i/Ku39
We ran into the cariboo yesterday.It was as curious about us as we were about it.http://ow.ly/i/Ku4E
If you look carefully here around the pencil  you can see the rock has been folded into a hairpin by the crater impact. http://t.co/La3X2Oxp
When was the last time you were in a place so pristine you could drink directly from the river? You can in the arctic. http://t.co/TvaTwVUn
Dr Osinksi & I venture out to crater rim.Expedition blog at http://t.co/lmHGCfQw
Expedition team lunch. Cass Raymond Salma Annemarie Oz & I.Excellent team and I will learn much from these geologists.http://ow.ly/i/KmOW
Found our first shatter cone!Strong supporting evidence that we are in a metorite impact crater.Some happy Geologists! http://t.co/O3syQo6q
Mother nature excavated this beautiful canyon showing us the effects of the crater below the surface.Beautiful! http://t.co/H7KXLgCk
Successful flight into the suspected crater.  The Twin Otter crew did a great job getting us and our supplies in.  http://t.co/XaVGTkHd
Midnight on Canada Day in the crater on Victoria Island.  The sun is just going in circles  land of the midnight sun! http://t.co/vUBPVndi
Happy Canada Day! Great to be in the true North on the occasion. My napkin from breakfast commemorates. http://t.co/19i5MQIv
Inukshuk near Cambridge Bay from tonight's hike. Head out tomorrow to investigate a potential meteorite impact crater. http://t.co/1xhph1sl
The North West Passage is still frozen. Heading out to explore Cambridge Bay on foot now. http://t.co/YuSvD9Ql
Great day at Alberta Aviation Museum with Hawk One. Ready for 'Pursue Your Dreams' presentation at 7pm.All are welcome http://t.co/63MXWECu
At Alberta Aviation Museum Edmonton from 1-4 & 7-930pm 2day touring Hawk One jet & speaking about Canada's Future in Space. All are welcome!
Found the Russian Space Shuttle Buran  on a river boat tour of Moscow. http://t.co/L3Vql1yR
Interesting piece of history.Ejection seat 4 Russian Space Shuttle Buran that flew once successfully but without crew. http://t.co/xxfgfhpp
When things go wrong.Learning options to eject capsule from rocket stack from launch to orbit.Can hit up to 20G. Ouch! http://t.co/maupx3yc
Cool class today. Norishige & I strapped into sim fully suited to practice life support operations. Great training! http://t.co/Oun7uATY
#Canadarm2 has grabbed the Dragon Capsule!  Congratulations to the team!
Norishige and I are keeping tabs on SpaceX capture from our Soyuz docking Sim. http://t.co/5yBwD2xO
Big day for SpaceX  ISS and Canadarm 2 as it will reach out and capture Dragon capsule and berth it to station!
Good news  I do fit in Soyuz! Here the suit has been pressurized and is rock hard to simulate a loss of pressure. http://t.co/3DmmrS4L
So they have a Russian Sokol suit tall enough for me at 6'2"  but now the moment of truth. Do I fit in the Soyuz seat? http://t.co/cuwRVXcN
Congrats to SpaceX!  Dragon is in orbit!
Will listen to the SpaceX launch from our classroom where we are learning Soyuz life support systems. Good luck to the SpaceX team!
SpaceX had a pad abort. Simple reality of such complex operations. I'm happy to see the rocket sitting safely on the pad following an abort.
Optimistically watching SpaceX launch in 25min from Star City at 4:55am EST. 1st commercial cargo to space station! http://t.co/pUQbEbGn
Setting up the dinner table in Soyuz spacecraft. If all goes as planned you will eat here for about 2.5 days. http://t.co/O2SsdCK6
A room with a view!. The Yuri Gagarin Training Complex in Star City as seen from my apartment. Here for 5 weeks! http://t.co/xBVS6UlW
Internet search NASA TV if you want to watch the Soyuz rocket taking 2 Cosmonauts  1 Astronaut to the Space Station at 10:01 PM EDT.
Met with students from Shaftesbury High. Check out video about cool balloon project. Future Canadian Greats! http://t.co/LX68Vgp3
Walking on Mars in this spacesuit at Telus World of Science! Great students there and at Steele Heights school 2day! http://t.co/DDvGQy3g
Our T-38 jet on the ramp in Austin Tx for a quick gas and go on a training mission today. Some great training! http://t.co/D46hso1z
Just been lowered into water for my first Deepworker sub dive. Very cool!! http://t.co/z56rj77X
Started my Nuytco Deepworker submarine training today. Looking forward to taking it for a flight tomorrow! http://t.co/xCCEW78G
Dr Osinski & Alaura Singleton examine samples fm meteorite impact crater in SK that we collected on expedition in July http://t.co/MaSRAN2W
Space Suit is on the stand  ready for me to squeeze into. http://t.co/SQVHqVV1
Tools for space walk training ready to go on my suit for a day of EVA training in the neutral buoyancy lab. http://t.co/rzzUigEu
Had a spectacular view of our planet when I arrived to work my Capcom shift today. Beautiful video view from ISS. http://t.co/6esNT0X0
Back at the Royal Military College of Canada 2day to speak to some of the cadets. Enjoyed the visit! http://t.co/0Uu9Mb09
Final Soyuz sim of this trip complete. Leaving Russia for Kingston  Ontario Canada for a few speaking engagements. http://t.co/6tvt8ZsH
Soyuz-ISS docking system class. Great mockup lets you see how the components work. Excellent redundancy designed in. http://t.co/o0a7nSdT
Soyuz is temperature regulated with air conditioning. Cycle this pump 120 times every 4hrs to remove water from system http://t.co/Lt7QM1b3
Goods news  I survived survival training. Not much room for survival gear in Soyuz  but what is there works! http://t.co/lrciEFDK
Starting survival exercise tomorrow. Training a 48hr wait for rescue after offsite Soyuz landing in winter. Forecast -20C. Could be worse.
Russian Segment ISS mockup received a new addition while I was away. A docked progress supply vehicle.(Right side) http://t.co/9NPlJgYn
A chance to check out Endeavour today at The Cape. What a magnificent Ship! http://t.co/ivsrufdG
Working Capcom. This ISS panel  returned from ISS  sits in mission control. Tribute to missions that built station. http://t.co/V9gEI6qP
Had a great month in Star City Russia training. 4 Russia Segment exams complete and now back to training in Houston.
If u see Russian panel like this  it's a bad day on orbit. Stopping airflow could be enough to smother fire in 0 g. http://t.co/mSmDn9UE
Norishige and I Trained 2day on how to change from Sokol suit into survival clothing while inside tiny Soyuz capsule. http://t.co/MPlR3jKl
Excellent Russian system that removes CO2 from Space Station air and emits to space. No expendables. Called воздух. http://t.co/SrxvClnO
Learnt how oxygen is produced from water 2day. Device is called Electron. Primary source of O2 for Russian segment. http://t.co/qrdpl9yb
View of Exp29 landing site  parachute & capsule. Snow is scorched by retro rockets that cushion impact. A little... http://t.co/2yryN7bE
Soyuz capsule of Exp 29 after landing 2day.Crew exits hatch on left of photo(closed).Parachute from side compartment. http://t.co/MqeGmTrr
Studied ventilation system on ISS 2day.Important in micro-gravity as warm air doesn't rise.A bubble of CO2 could kill you while you sleep.
A cosmonauts bedroom aboard station.  You sleep or float vertically along the wall. Talk about a room with view! http://t.co/z0N7FQej
This aluminum alloy is used to construct Russian modules. Only 2mm between you and vacuum of space. Proven technology! http://t.co/jlxtbJT0
Classmate Norishige Kanai & I taking class on Russian FGB module. Primarily used for storage. Was 1st module launched. http://t.co/OSMjeGCl
Learning how Russian segment is controlled via complex computer network. Crew uses this laptop to control station. http://t.co/rJz9DTUr
Happy 2B back in Star City Russia training. Some light reading from my instructors on Russia space station segment! http://t.co/0KsvSWUW
Amazing video of our plant from Space Station. I'm always amazed by the perspective of how thin our atmosphere is!  http://t.co/vjXyFerS
Nice picture of the Russian progress cargo vehicle docking to space station yesterday. Supplies for the crew! http://t.co/JXVzZI21
Working on EVA for @Cmdr_Hadfield today at pool. Cool Orion test article for capsule water landing in bldg today. http://t.co/PIixLzzz
Want 2 help with exploration science?  Visit neemo.zooniverse.org. Human eyes are better than computers at many things.
The NEWTSUBs will be used in @NASA_NEEMO to simulate a space exploration vehicle that astronauts will use at asteroid.  http://t.co/cqp27iuy
Preparing subs for @NASA_NEEMO mission on Liberty Star at KSC 2Day. This Ship used to retrieve SRBs from Shuttle.  http://t.co/8ArgyhQq
First look at Life Support Buoy that supplies underwater home for @Astro_DavidS NEEMO mission. Great 1st dive!   http://t.co/pyjeezTq
Providing ground control for @Cmdr_Hadfield Spacewalk sched for Jan 2013 during a training run today. Going well.  http://t.co/RirJpGRk
Prepping for EVA (space walk) run in pool tomorrow. Techs have my suit ready. Lots of effort to keep us alive in suit. http://t.co/5Ph2Lc30
Working an International Space Station CAPCOM sim shift tonight with JAXA. Sim http://t.co/eDnhhPfH
Got the office up and running for the day. Development run for @Cmdr_Hadfield's planned EVA during his Expedition. Fun! http://t.co/eEXDADw6
Flew aspiring fighter pilot Ryan Clarke today. 9 awesome CF-18 missions with the CF complete! Back to Houston now. http://t.co/FfPMa12
Pic from flight back to Edmonton airport after a dog fight training mission in the CF-18 Hornet today. Great flight! http://t.co/Q9lN8ze
Just arrived at CFB Cold Lake Alberta. Looking forward to the challenge of flying the mighty Hornet again!   http://t.co/1gZGb3I
Last day in Star City. People still leave flowers to honour Yuri Gagarin's first steps for human exploration of space. http://t.co/fEcMzr4
